About me

Let's learn from each other

Bio

I made a point of learning in college a little bit of everything of my own accord. From AI to web development, dipping my toes in signal processing, computational geometry, graphical computing, and going through the usual curriculum of algorithm optimization, statistics, calculus, and linear algebra, all of which I enjoyed very much, while also learning game development with my friends from UGD. I even took a course on creative writing through Coursera back when the quarantines began.

That is to say, I will and want to learn. More than that, I'm eager to apply this knowledge.
Let me show you.

Programmer

Analyse, learn, do.

Never arrive unarmed to a gunfight. Problems are seldon unsolved, or at least much easier to deal with if when one knows the right tools and the right math. Make sure you understand the problem, then deal with it appropriately. And if you don't know these tools? Learn them. What good will one do in a gunfight without knowing how to use their gun?

It's important to be quick and know how to improvise, but more often than not, it's like a surgery; do what you know, lern what you must, minimize the collateral damage, and leave no trace. Never messy, always SOLID. Code is made to be read by humans, after all.

On occasion, however, one may find a team using hammers to drive in screws. Be ready to teach them. Be ready to join them. Be ready to rely and be relied on.

Full Stack Developer

Never do things halfway

Colleges are (in)famously lousy at teaching programming languages. My experience was no different, but perhaps it was for the best; I don't take my knowledge of tools for granted, and I'm ready to learn a language, library, or framework in a moment's notice. Which is also why I had to learn both sides of the trade. How could I pick based on superficial impressions?

How could I choose not to learn an entire half of the art?

Tech Artist

Art & Programming

Back during high-school, I was afraid I'd have to choose between art and programming. When I became a programmer, I learned I could choose both.

It is a beautiful thing, to make art as a programmer. It's both work and hobby. Jack of all trades and master of quite a few. It takes effort, but its deeply rewarding. Purposeful.

I can't imagine a world where games aren't my medium of choice.
